article.title: Recellularization of Decellularized Lung Scaffolds Is Enhanced by Dynamic Suspension Culture
article.abstract: Strategies are needed to improve repopulation of decellularized lung scaffolds with stromal and functional epithelial cells.

sections.introduction: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) affects over 64 million people worldwide and is predicted by the World Health Organization to become the third leading cause of mortality by 2030.
sections.methods: MSCs from bone marrow of adult C57BL/6 mice were obtained from the NCRR/NIH Center for Preparation and Distribution of Adult Stem cells at Texas A&M University.
sections.results: Decellularized lung scaffolds recellularized with MSCs for a total of 14 days had more abundant cells in the bioreactor as compared to static conditions.
sections.discussion: A promising approach for ex vivo lung engineering is the repopulation of decellularized lung scaffolds with autologous stem and/or progenitor cells derived from the actual transplant recipient.

article.insights_summary: Dynamic suspension culture enhances recellularization efficiency and viability of decellularized lung scaffolds.
article.acknowledgments: We are grateful to Jenny Pattengill (Mayo Clinic Histology Core Facility) for processing samples for histology.
